dn19:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
dn19:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

dn19:1.3.pli: Atha kho pañcasikho gandhabbaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ gijjhakūṭaṃ pabbataṃ obhāsetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho pañcasikho gandhabbaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn19:1.3.eng: Then, late at night, the centaur Pañcasikha, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
dn19:1.3.comm: We were introduced to Pañcasikha in DN 18, which is similar to the current sutta in many other details as well. Thus this sutta can be considered as a distant cousin to the Mahāparinibbāna cycle.

dn19:1.4.pli: “yaṃ kho me, bhante, devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ, ārocemi taṃ bhagavato”ti.
dn19:1.4.eng: “Sir, I would tell you of what I heard and learned directly from the gods of the thirty-three.”

dn19:2.1.pli: “Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni tadahuposathe pannarase pavāraṇāya puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā kevalakappā ca devā tāvatiṃsā sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā;
dn19:2.1.eng: “Sir, it was more than a few days ago—on the fifteenth day sabbath on the full moon day at the invitation to admonish held at the end of the rainy season—when all the gods of the thirty-three were sitting together in the Hall of Clear Right.
dn19:2.1.comm: The council of gods described by Janavasabha at DN 18:12.1, while otherwise similar, took place at the entry to a rainy season, whereas this one is at the end of a rainy season. This cannot have been the Buddha’s last rains, for he was already in Vajji by then.

dn19:2.2.pli: mahatī ca dibbaparisā samantato nisinnā honti, cattāro ca mahārājāno catuddisā nisinnā honti;
dn19:2.2.eng: A large assembly of gods was sitting all around, and the four great kings were seated at the four quarters.

dn19:2.3.pli: puratthimāya disāya dhataraṭṭho mahārājā pacchimābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
dn19:2.3.eng: The Great King Dhataraṭṭha was seated to the east, facing west, in front of his gods.

dn19:2.4.pli: dakkhiṇāya disāya virūḷhako mahārājā uttarābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
dn19:2.4.eng: The Great King Virūḷhaka was seated to the south, facing north, in front of his gods.

dn19:2.5.pli: pacchimāya disāya virūpakkho mahārājā puratthābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā;
dn19:2.5.eng: The Great King Virūpakkha was seated to the west, facing east, in front of his gods.

dn19:2.6.pli: uttarāya disāya vessavaṇo mahārājā dakkhiṇābhimukho nisinno hoti deve purakkhatvā.
dn19:2.6.eng: The Great King Vessavaṇa was seated to the north, facing south, in front of his gods.

dn19:2.7.pli: Yadā, bhante, kevalakappā ca devā tāvatiṃsā sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā, mahatī ca dibbaparisā samantato nisinnā honti, cattāro ca mahārājāno catuddisā nisinnā honti, idaṃ nesaṃ hoti āsanasmiṃ;
dn19:2.7.eng: When the gods of the thirty-three have a gathering like this, that is how they are seated.

dn19:3.1.pli: Ye te, bhante, devā bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ caritvā adhunūpapannā tāvatiṃsakāyaṃ, te aññe deve atirocanti vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
dn19:3.1.eng: Sir, those gods who had been recently reborn in the company of the thirty-three after leading the spiritual life under the Buddha outshine the other gods in beauty and glory.

dn19:3.2.pli: Tena sudaṃ, bhante, devā tāvatiṃsā attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā;
dn19:3.2.eng: The gods of the thirty-three became uplifted and overjoyed at that, full of rapture and happiness, saying,

dn19:3.3.pli: ‘dibbā vata bho kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
dn19:3.3.eng: ‘The heavenly hosts swell, while the titan hosts dwindle!’

dn19:3.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sampasādaṃ viditvā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
dn19:3.4.eng: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, celebrated with these verses:

dn19:3.8.eng: and the clear rightness of the teaching;

dn19:3.11.eng: who have come here after leading

dn19:3.12.eng: the spiritual life under the Buddha!

dn19:3.16.eng: of he whose wisdom is vast.

dn19:3.20.eng: and the clear rightness of the teaching!’

dn19:3.21.pli: Tena sudaṃ, bhante, devā tāvatiṃsā bhiyyoso mattāya attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā;
dn19:3.21.eng: The gods of the thirty-three became even more uplifted and overjoyed at that, full of rapture and happiness, saying,

dn19:3.22.pli: ‘dibbā vata bho, kāyā paripūrenti, hāyanti asurakāyā’ti.
dn19:3.22.eng: ‘The heavenly hosts swell, while the titan hosts dwindle!’

dn19:4.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sampasādaṃ viditvā deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
dn19:4.1.eng: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed them,

dn19:4.2.pli: ‘iccheyyātha no tumhe, mārisā, tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sotun’ti?
dn19:4.2.eng: ‘Gentlemen, would you like to hear eight genuine praises of the Buddha?’
dn19:4.2.comm: For “genuine praise” (yathābhucce vaṇṇe), see DN 1:1.28.1.

dn19:4.3.pli: ‘Icchāma mayaṃ, mārisa, tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sotun’ti.

dn19:4.4.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi:
dn19:4.4.eng: Then Sakka proffered these eight genuine praises of the Buddha:
dn19:4.4.comm: This set of eight is not found elsewhere. | “Proffered” is payirudāhāsi, a unique term in early texts.

dn19:5.1.eng: ‘What do the good gods of the thirty-three think?
dn19:5.1.comm: Sakka adopts the same rhetorical style as Sanaṅkumāra (DN 18:20.2).

dn19:5.2.pli: Yāvañca so bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn19:5.2.eng: How the Buddha has acted for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!

dn19:5.3.pli: Evaṃ bahujanahitāya paṭipannaṃ bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:5.3.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who has such sympathy for the world, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:6.1.pli: Svākkhāto kho pana tena bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhi.
dn19:6.1.eng: Also, the Buddha has explained the teaching well—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

dn19:6.2.pli: Evaṃ opaneyyikassa dhammassa desetāraṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:6.2.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who explains such a relevant teaching, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:7.1.pli: “Idaṃ kusalan”ti kho pana tena bhagavatā supaññattaṃ, “idaṃ akusalan”ti supaññattaṃ.
dn19:7.1.eng: Also, the Buddha has well described what is skillful and what is unskillful,

dn19:7.2.pli: “Idaṃ sāvajjaṃ idaṃ anavajjaṃ, idaṃ sevitabbaṃ idaṃ na sevitabbaṃ, idaṃ hīnaṃ idaṃ paṇītaṃ, idaṃ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan”ti supaññattaṃ.
dn19:7.2.eng: what is blameworthy and what is blameless, what should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated, what is inferior and what is superior, and what is on the side of dark and the side of bright.

dn19:7.3.pli: Evaṃ kusalākusalasāvajjānavajjasevitabbāsevitabbahīnapaṇītakaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgānaṃ dhammānaṃ paññāpetāraṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:7.3.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so clearly describes all these things, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:8.1.pli: Supaññattā kho pana tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṃ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā, saṃsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
dn19:8.1.eng: Also, the Buddha has well described the practice that leads to extinguishment for his disciples. And extinguishment converges with the practice,

dn19:8.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gaṅgodakaṃ yamunodakena saṃsandati sameti;
dn19:8.2.eng: as the waters of the Ganges join together and converge with the waters of the Yamuna.
dn19:8.2.comm: I don’t think this idea is found elsewhere in quite this way. Normally it is said that the path leads to Nibbāna like the rivers lead to the ocean (eg. SN 45.114:1.1).

dn19:8.3.pli: evameva supaññattā tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṃ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā, saṃsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.

dn19:8.4.pli: Evaṃ nibbānagāminiyā paṭipadāya paññāpetāraṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:8.4.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so clearly describes the practice that leads to extinguishment for his disciples, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:9.1.pli: Abhinipphanno kho pana tassa bhagavato lābho abhinipphanno siloko, yāva maññe khattiyā sampiyāyamānarūpā viharanti, vigatamado kho pana so bhagavā āhāraṃ āhāreti.
dn19:9.1.eng: Also, possessions and popularity have accrued to the Buddha, so much that you’d think it would thrill even the aristocrats. But he takes his food free of vanity.

dn19:9.2.pli: Evaṃ vigatamadaṃ āhāraṃ āharayamānaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:9.2.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who takes their food so free of vanity, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:10.1.pli: Laddhasahāyo kho pana so bhagavā sekhānañceva paṭipannānaṃ khīṇāsavānañca vusitavataṃ.
dn19:10.1.eng: Also, the Buddha has gained companions, both trainees who are practicing, and those with defilements ended who have completed their journey.

dn19:10.2.pli: Te bhagavā apanujja ekārāmataṃ anuyutto viharati.
dn19:10.2.eng: The Buddha is committed to the joy of solitude, but doesn’t send them away.
dn19:10.2.comm: This is normally true, but in some cases the Buddha left a badly-behaved community (MN 48), dismissed misbehaving monks (eg. AN 8.10:2.2), or even dismissed a large community (MN 67). | The “joy of solitude” is ekārāmataṁ .

dn19:10.3.pli: Evaṃ ekārāmataṃ anuyuttaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:10.3.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, so committed to the joy of solitude, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:11.1.pli: Yathāvādī kho pana so bhagavā tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī, iti yathāvādī tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī.
dn19:11.1.eng: Also, the Buddha does as he says, and says as he does, thus: he does as he says, and says as he does.
dn19:11.1.comm: Also at DN 29:29.5, AN 4.23:4.1, and Iti 112:5.1.

dn19:11.2.pli: Evaṃ dhammānudhammappaṭipannaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
dn19:11.2.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so practices in line with the teaching, apart from the Buddha.

dn19:12.1.pli: Tiṇṇavicikiccho kho pana so bhagavā vigatakathaṅkatho pariyositasaṅkappo ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyaṃ.
dn19:12.1.eng: Also, the Buddha has gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision. He has achieved all he wished for regarding the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.
dn19:12.1.comm: Pariyositasaṅkappo (“achieved all he wished for”) is a synonym of the more common paripuṇṇasaṅkappo (eg. MN 29:2.5).

dn19:12.2.pli: Evaṃ tiṇṇavicikicchaṃ vigatakathaṅkathaṃ pariyositasaṅkappaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā’ti.
dn19:12.2.eng: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who has achieved these things, apart from the Buddha.’

dn19:12.3.pli: Ime kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
dn19:12.3.eng: These are the eight genuine praises of the Buddha proffered by Sakka.

dn19:12.4.pli: Tena sudaṃ, bhante, devā tāvatiṃsā bhiyyoso mattāya attamanā honti pamuditā pītisomanassajātā bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sutvā.
dn19:12.4.eng: Hearing them, the gods of the thirty-three became even more uplifted and overjoyed.

dn19:13.2.pli: ‘aho vata, mārisā, cattāro sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjeyyuṃ dhammañca deseyyuṃ yathariva bhagavā.
dn19:13.2.eng: ‘If only four fully awakened Buddhas might arise in the world and teach the Dhamma, just like the Blessed One!

dn19:13.3.pli: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
dn19:13.3.eng: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’

dn19:13.5.pli: ‘tiṭṭhantu, mārisā, cattāro sammāsambuddhā, aho vata, mārisā, tayo sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjeyyuṃ dhammañca deseyyuṃ yathariva bhagavā.
dn19:13.5.eng: ‘Let alone four fully awakened Buddhas; if only three fully awakened Buddhas,

dn19:13.6.pli: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.

dn19:13.8.pli: ‘tiṭṭhantu, mārisā, tayo sammāsambuddhā, aho vata, mārisā, dve sammāsambuddhā loke uppajjeyyuṃ dhammañca deseyyuṃ yathariva bhagavā.
dn19:13.8.eng: or two fully awakened Buddhas might arise in the world and teach the Dhamma, just like the Blessed One!

dn19:13.9.pli: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
dn19:13.9.eng: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’

dn19:14.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse etadavoca:
dn19:14.1.eng: When they said this, Sakka said,

dn19:14.2.pli: ‘aṭṭhānaṃ kho etaṃ, mārisā, anavakāso, yaṃ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhā apubbaṃ acarimaṃ uppajjeyyuṃ, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn19:14.2.eng: ‘It is impossible, gentlemen, for two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas to arise in the same solar system at the same time.
dn19:14.2.comm: This impossibility is also at AN 1.277:1.1 and MN 115:14.1. | “In one solar system” (ekissā lokadhātuyā): a single lokadhātu encompasses a single terrestrial world with a single moon and sun.

dn19:14.3.pli: Aho vata, mārisā, so bhagavā appābādho appātaṅko ciraṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ tiṭṭheyya.
dn19:14.3.eng: May that Blessed One be healthy and well, and remain with us for a long time!
dn19:14.3.comm: It is not common to wish for the Buddha’s long life, but we do find this sentiment expressed in a conversation between Sāriputta and Ānanda (SN 21.2:3.5).

dn19:14.4.pli: Tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
dn19:14.4.eng: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’

dn19:14.5.pli: Atha kho, bhante, yenatthena devā tāvatiṃsā sudhammāyaṃ sabhāyaṃ sannisinnā honti sannipatitā, taṃ atthaṃ cintayitvā taṃ atthaṃ mantayitvā vuttavacanāpi taṃ cattāro mahārājāno tasmiṃ atthe honti.
dn19:14.5.eng: Then the gods of the thirty-three, having considered and deliberated on the matter for which they were seated together in the Hall of Clear Right, advised and instructed the four great kings on the subject.

dn19:14.6.pli: Paccānusiṭṭhavacanāpi taṃ cattāro mahārājāno tasmiṃ atthe honti, sakesu sakesu āsanesu ṭhitā avipakkantā.
dn19:14.6.eng: Each one, having been advised, stood at his own seat without leaving.

dn19:14.10.eng: they stood by their own seats.

dn19:15.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, uttarāya disāya uḷāro āloko sañjāyi, obhāso pāturahosi atikkammeva devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ.
dn19:15.1.eng: Then in the northern quarter a magnificent light arose and radiance appeared, surpassing the glory of the gods.

dn19:15.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
dn19:15.2.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,

dn19:15.3.pli: ‘yathā kho, mārisā, nimittāni dissanti, uḷāro āloko sañjāyati, obhāso pātubhavati, brahmā pātubhavissati;
dn19:15.3.eng: ‘As indicated by the signs—light arising and radiance appearing—the Divinity will appear. For this is the precursor for the appearance of the Divinity, namely light arising and radiance appearing.’

dn19:15.4.pli: brahmuno hetaṃ pubbanimittaṃ pātubhāvāya, yadidaṃ āloko sañjāyati obhāso pātubhavatīti.

dn19:15.7.eng: For this is the sign of the Divinity:

dn19:16.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, devā tāvatiṃsā yathāsakesu āsanesu nisīdiṃsu:
dn19:16.1.eng: Then the gods of the thirty-three sat in their own seats, saying,

dn19:16.2.pli: ‘obhāsametaṃ ñassāma, yaṃvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṃ gamissāmā’ti.
dn19:16.2.eng: ‘We shall find out what has caused that light, and only when we have realized it shall we go to it.’

dn19:16.3.eng: And the four great kings did likewise.

dn19:16.4.pli: ‘obhāsametaṃ ñassāma, yaṃvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṃ gamissāmā’ti.

dn19:16.5.pli: Idaṃ sutvā devā tāvatiṃsā ekaggā samāpajjiṃsu:
dn19:16.5.eng: Hearing that, the gods of the thirty-three agreed in unison,

dn19:16.6.pli: ‘obhāsametaṃ ñassāma, yaṃvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṃ gamissāmā’ti.
dn19:16.6.eng: ‘We shall find out what has caused that light, and only when we have realized it shall we go to it.’

dn19:16.7.pli: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pātubhavati, oḷārikaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinimminitvā pātubhavati.
dn19:16.7.eng: When the divinity Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the thirty-three, he does so after manifesting in a solid corporeal form.

dn19:16.8.pli: Yo kho pana, bhante, brahmuno pakativaṇṇo, anabhisambhavanīyo so devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ cakkhupathasmiṃ.
dn19:16.8.eng: For a Divinity’s normal appearance is imperceptible in the visual range of the gods of the thirty-three.

dn19:16.9.pli: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
dn19:16.9.eng: When the divinity Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the thirty-three, he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory,

dn19:16.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, so vaṇṇo viggaho mānusaṃ viggahaṃ atirocati;
dn19:16.10.eng: as a golden statue outshines the human form.

dn19:16.11.pli: evameva kho, bhante, yadā brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.

dn19:16.12.pli: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pātubhavati, na tassaṃ parisāyaṃ koci devo abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimanteti.
dn19:16.12.eng: When the divinity Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the thirty-three, not a single god in that assembly greets him by bowing down or rising up or inviting him to a seat.

dn19:16.13.eng: They all sit silently on their couches with their joined palms raised, thinking,

dn19:16.14.pli: ‘yassadāni devassa pallaṅkaṃ icchissati brahmā sanaṅkumāro, tassa devassa pallaṅke nisīdissatī’ti.
dn19:16.14.eng: ‘Now the divinity Sanaṅkumāra will sit on the couch of whatever god he chooses.’

dn19:16.15.pli: Yassa kho pana, bhante, devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṃ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṃ, uḷāraṃ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṃ.
dn19:16.15.eng: And the god on whose couch the Divinity sits is overjoyed and brimming with happiness,

dn19:17.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto adhunābhisitto rajjena, uḷāraṃ so labhati vedapaṭilābhaṃ, uḷāraṃ so labhati somanassapaṭilābhaṃ;
dn19:17.1.eng: like a king on the day of his coronation.

dn19:17.2.pli: evameva kho, bhante, yassa devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṃ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṃ, uḷāraṃ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṃ.

dn19:17.3.pli: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ sampasādaṃ viditvā antarahito imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
dn19:17.3.eng: Seeing the joy of those gods, the divinity Sanaṅkumāra celebrated with these verses:

dn19:17.7.eng: and the clear rightness of the teaching;

dn19:17.10.eng: who have come here after leading

dn19:17.11.eng: the spiritual life under the Buddha!

dn19:17.15.eng: of he whose wisdom is vast.

dn19:17.19.eng: and the clear rightness of the teaching!’

dn19:18.1.eng: That is the topic on which the divinity Sanaṅkumāra spoke.

dn19:18.2.pli: Imamatthaṃ, bhante, brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhāsato aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti vissaṭṭho ca viññeyyo ca mañju ca savanīyo ca bindu ca avisārī ca gambhīro ca ninnādī ca.
dn19:18.2.eng: And while he was speaking on that topic, his voice had eight qualities: it was clear, comprehensible, charming, audible, lucid, undistorted, deep, and resonant.

dn19:18.3.pli: Yathāparisaṃ kho pana, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sarena viññāpeti, na cassa bahiddhā parisāya ghoso niccharati.
dn19:18.3.eng: He makes sure his voice is intelligible as far as the assembly goes, but the sound doesn’t extend outside the assembly.

dn19:18.4.pli: Yassa kho pana, bhante, evaṃ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti, so vuccati ‘brahmassaro’ti.
dn19:18.4.eng: When someone has a voice like this, they’re said to have the voice of the Divinity.

dn19:19.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, devā tāvatiṃsā brahmānaṃ sanaṅkumāraṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn19:19.1.eng: Then the gods of the thirty-three said to the divinity Sanaṅkumāra,

dn19:19.2.eng: ‘Good, Great Divinity! Having appraised this, we rejoice.
dn19:19.2.comm: “Having appraised” (saṅkhāya) is glossed by the commentary with “having known” (jānitvā). Compare the discussion on “judgmentalism” at DN 1:1.3.1.

dn19:19.3.pli: atthi ca sakkena devānamindena tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhuccā vaṇṇā bhāsitā;
dn19:19.3.eng: And there are the eight genuine praises of the Buddha spoken by Sakka—

dn19:19.4.eng: having appraised them, too, we rejoice.’

dn19:19.6.pli: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
dn19:19.6.eng: Then the Divinity said to Sakka,

dn19:19.7.pli: ‘sādhu, devānaminda, mayampi tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe suṇeyyāmā’ti.
dn19:19.7.eng: ‘It would be good, lord of gods, if I could also hear the eight genuine praises of the Buddha.’

dn19:19.8.pli: ‘Evaṃ, mahābrahme’ti kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
dn19:19.8.eng: Saying, ‘Yes, Great Divinity,’ Sakka repeated the eight genuine praises for him.

dn19:20.2.pli: Yāvañca so bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.

dn19:20.3.pli: Evaṃ bahujanahitāya paṭipannaṃ bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:21.1.pli: Svākkhāto kho pana tena bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhi.

dn19:21.2.pli: Evaṃ opaneyyikassa dhammassa desetāraṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:22.1.pli: “Idaṃ kusalan”ti kho pana tena bhagavatā supaññattaṃ, “idaṃ akusalan”ti supaññattaṃ, “idaṃ sāvajjaṃ idaṃ anavajjaṃ, idaṃ sevitabbaṃ idaṃ na sevitabbaṃ, idaṃ hīnaṃ idaṃ paṇītaṃ, idaṃ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan”ti supaññattaṃ.

dn19:22.3.pli: Imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:23.1.pli: Supaññattā kho pana tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṃ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā saṃsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.

dn19:23.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gaṅgodakaṃ yamunodakena saṃsandati sameti;

dn19:23.3.pli: evameva supaññattā tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṃ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā saṃsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.

dn19:23.4.pli: Evaṃ nibbānagāminiyā paṭipadāya paññāpetāraṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:24.1.pli: Abhinipphanno kho pana tassa bhagavato lābho abhinipphanno siloko, yāva maññe khattiyā sampiyāyamānarūpā viharanti.

dn19:24.2.pli: Vigatamado kho pana so bhagavā āhāraṃ āhāreti.

dn19:24.3.pli: Evaṃ vigatamadaṃ āhāraṃ āharayamānaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:25.1.pli: Laddhasahāyo kho pana so bhagavā sekhānañceva paṭipannānaṃ khīṇāsavānañca vusitavataṃ, te bhagavā apanujja ekārāmataṃ anuyutto viharati.

dn19:25.2.pli: Evaṃ ekārāmataṃ anuyuttaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:26.1.pli: Yathāvādī kho pana so bhagavā tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī;

dn19:26.3.pli: Evaṃ dhammānudhammappaṭippannaṃ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.

dn19:27.1.pli: Tiṇṇavicikiccho kho pana so bhagavā vigatakathaṅkatho pariyositasaṅkappo ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyaṃ.

dn19:27.2.pli: Evaṃ tiṇṇavicikicchaṃ vigatakathaṅkathaṃ pariyositasaṅkappaṃ ajjhāsayaṃ ādibrahmacariyaṃ.

dn19:27.3.pli: Imināpaṅgena samannāgataṃ satthāraṃ neva atītaṃse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā’ti.

dn19:28.1.pli: Ime kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.

dn19:28.2.pli: Tena sudaṃ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro attamano hoti pamudito pītisomanassajāto bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sutvā.
dn19:28.2.eng: Hearing them, the divinity Sanaṅkumāra was uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.

dn19:28.3.pli: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro oḷārikaṃ attabhāvaṃ abhinimminitvā kumāravaṇṇī hutvā pañcasikho devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ pāturahosi.
dn19:28.3.eng: Then the divinity Sanaṅkumāra manifested in a solid corporeal form, taking on the appearance of the youth Pañcasikha, and appeared to the gods of the thirty-three.

dn19:28.4.pli: So vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīdi.
dn19:28.4.eng: Rising into the air, he sat cross-legged in the sky,

dn19:28.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, balavā puriso supaccatthate vā pallaṅke same vā bhūmibhāge pallaṅkena nisīdeyya;
dn19:28.5.eng: like a strong man might sit cross-legged on a well-appointed couch or on level ground.

dn19:28.6.pli: evameva kho, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
dn19:28.6.eng: There he addressed the gods of the thirty-three:

dn19:28.8.pli: ‘Taṃ kiṃ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṃsā, yāva dīgharattaṃ mahāpaññova so bhagavā ahosi.
dn19:28.8.eng: ‘What do the gods of the thirty-three think about the extent of the Buddha’s great wisdom?

dn19:29.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bho, rājā disampati nāma ahosi.
dn19:29.1.eng: Once upon a time, there was a king named Disampati.
dn19:29.1.comm: Disampati means “head of the directions”, i.e. king of all the land. He and his story are found nowhere else in the early texts.

dn19:29.2.pli: Disampatissa rañño govindo nāma brāhmaṇo purohito ahosi.
dn19:29.2.eng: He had a brahmin high priest named the Steward.
dn19:29.2.comm: “Steward” is Govinda, literally “lord of cows”. The “high priest” (purohita) was a hereditary office, a learned ritualist and adviser attached to a specific family. For royal families the post could be highly contested. The closeness of the role is shown in that aristocratic families could be referred to by the lineage of the high priest.

dn19:29.3.pli: Disampatissa rañño reṇu nāma kumāro putto ahosi.
dn19:29.3.eng: Disampati’s son was the prince named Reṇu,
dn19:29.3.comm: While the current sutta does not explicitly identify their realm, Dīpavaṁsa iii 40 records Disampati and Reṇu as kings of Kāsi. This fits with the geographical layout depicted in this sutta, with Kāsi at the center. The story, then, depicts the establishment of Brahmanical kings across India from Kāsi.

dn19:29.4.pli: Govindassa brāhmaṇassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo putto ahosi.
dn19:29.4.eng: while the Steward’s son was the student named Jotipāla.
dn19:29.4.comm: Jotipāla means “guardian of the sacred flame”, i.e. someone who maintains the Vedic fire ritual (see below at DN 19:47.26). There was another Jotipāla in the time of Buddha Kassapa at MN 81:6.2, and another who was a religious founder of the past (AN 6.54:18.1, AN 7.73:2.5). Despite the popularity of the name in Pali, it does not seem to appear in Sanskrit sources. Given that it appears in Pali only in legendary contexts, it is probably a vocational epithet.

dn19:29.5.pli: Iti reṇu ca rājaputto jotipālo ca māṇavo aññe ca cha khattiyā iccete aṭṭha sahāyā ahesuṃ.
dn19:29.5.eng: There were Reṇu the prince, Jotipāla the student, and six other aristocrats; these eight became friends.

dn19:29.6.pli: Atha kho, bho, ahorattānaṃ accayena govindo brāhmaṇo kālamakāsi.
dn19:29.6.eng: In due course the brahmin Steward passed away.

dn19:29.7.pli: Govinde brāhmaṇe kālaṅkate rājā disampati paridevesi:
dn19:29.7.eng: At his passing, King Disampati lamented,

dn19:29.8.pli: “yasmiṃ vata, bho, mayaṃ samaye govinde brāhmaṇe sabbakiccāni sammā vossajjitvā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārema, tasmiṃ no samaye govindo brāhmaṇo kālaṅkato”ti.
dn19:29.8.eng: “At a time when I have relinquished all my duties to the brahmin Steward and amuse myself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, he passes away!”
dn19:29.8.comm: The king’s only care, it seems, is not for the passing of his friend, but that he no longer gets to indulge in whatever he wants.

dn19:29.9.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bho, reṇu rājaputto rājānaṃ disampatiṃ etadavoca:
dn19:29.9.eng: When he said this, Prince Reṇu said to him,

dn19:29.10.pli: “mā kho tvaṃ, deva, govinde brāhmaṇe kālaṅkate atibāḷhaṃ paridevesi.
dn19:29.10.eng: “Sire, don’t lament too much at the Steward’s passing.

dn19:29.11.pli: Atthi, deva, govindassa brāhmaṇassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo putto paṇḍitataro ceva pitarā, alamatthadasataro ceva pitarā;
dn19:29.11.eng: He has a son named Jotipāla, who is even more astute and expert than his father.

dn19:29.12.pli: yepissa pitā atthe anusāsi, tepi jotipālasseva māṇavassa anusāsaniyā”ti.
dn19:29.12.eng: He should manage the affairs that were managed by his father.”

dn19:30.0.eng: 6. The Story of the Great Steward

dn19:30.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, rājā disampati aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
dn19:30.1.eng: So King Disampati addressed one of his men,

dn19:30.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yena jotipālo māṇavo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ evaṃ vadehi:
dn19:30.2.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to the student Jotipāla, and say to him,

dn19:30.3.pli: ‘bhavamatthu bhavantaṃ jotipālaṃ, rājā disampati bhavantaṃ jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantayati, rājā disampati bhoto jotipālassa māṇavassa dassanakāmo’”ti.
dn19:30.3.eng: ‘Best wishes, Jotipāla! You are summoned by King Disampati; he wants to see you.’”

dn19:30.4.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho, bho, so puriso disampatissa rañño paṭissutvā yena jotipālo māṇavo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca:
dn19:30.4.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.

dn19:30.5.pli: “bhavamatthu bhavantaṃ jotipālaṃ, rājā disampati bhavantaṃ jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantayati, rājā disampati bhoto jotipālassa māṇavassa dassanakāmo”ti.

dn19:30.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho, bho, jotipālo māṇavo tassa purisassa paṭissutvā yena rājā disampati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā disampatinā raññā saddhiṃ sammodi;
dn19:30.6.eng: Then Jotipāla went to the king and exchanged greetings with him.

dn19:30.7.pli: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho, bho, jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ rājā disampati etadavoca:
dn19:30.7.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the king said to him,

dn19:30.8.pli: “anusāsatu no bhavaṃ jotipālo, mā no bhavaṃ jotipālo anusāsaniyā paccabyāhāsi.
dn19:30.8.eng: “May you, Jotipāla, manage my affairs—please don’t turn me down!

dn19:30.9.pli: Pettike taṃ ṭhāne ṭhapessāmi, govindiye abhisiñcissāmī”ti.
dn19:30.9.eng: I shall appoint you to your father’s position, and anoint you as Steward.”
dn19:30.9.comm: This shows that Govinda is an office rather than a personal name.

dn19:30.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho, bho, so jotipālo māṇavo disampatissa rañño paccassosi.

dn19:31.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, rājā disampati jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ govindiye abhisiñci, taṃ pettike ṭhāne ṭhapesi.
dn19:31.1.eng: So the king anointed him as Steward and appointed him to his father’s position.

dn19:31.2.pli: Abhisitto jotipālo māṇavo govindiye pettike ṭhāne ṭhapito yepissa pitā atthe anusāsi tepi atthe anusāsati, yepissa pitā atthe nānusāsi tepi atthe anusāsati;
dn19:31.2.eng: After his appointment, the Steward Jotipāla managed both the affairs that his father had managed, and other affairs that his father had not managed.
dn19:31.2.comm: Following the Mahāsaṅgīti reading rather than the PTS (nānusāsi … nānusāsati). It seems required by the context that he does more than his father.

dn19:31.3.pli: yepissa pitā kammante abhisambhosi tepi kammante abhisambhoti, yepissa pitā kammante nābhisambhosi tepi kammante abhisambhoti.
dn19:31.3.eng: He organized both the works that his father had organized, and other works that his father had not organized.

dn19:31.4.eng: When people noticed this they said,

dn19:31.5.pli: “govindo vata, bho, brāhmaṇo, mahāgovindo vata, bho, brāhmaṇo”ti.
dn19:31.5.eng: “The brahmin is indeed a Steward, a Great Steward!”

dn19:31.6.pli: Iminā kho evaṃ, bho, pariyāyena jotipālassa māṇavassa govindo mahāgovindotveva samaññā udapādi.
dn19:31.6.eng: And that’s how the student Jotipāla came to be known as the Great Steward.

dn19:32.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
dn19:32.1.eng: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats and said,

dn19:32.2.pli: “disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitaṃ?
dn19:32.2.eng: “King Disampati is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. Who knows how long he has to live?

dn19:32.3.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati, yaṃ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro reṇuṃ rājaputtaṃ rajje abhisiñceyyuṃ.
dn19:32.3.eng: It’s likely that when he passes away the king-makers will anoint Prince Reṇu as king.

dn19:32.4.pli: Āyantu, bhonto, yena reṇu rājaputto tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṃ rājaputtaṃ evaṃ vadetha:
dn19:32.4.eng: Come, sirs, go to Prince Reṇu and say,

dn19:32.5.pli: ‘mayaṃ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā, yaṃsukho bhavaṃ taṃsukhā mayaṃ, yaṃdukkho bhavaṃ taṃdukkhā mayaṃ.
dn19:32.5.eng: ‘Prince Reṇu, we are your friends, dear, beloved, and cherished. We have shared your joys and sorrows.

dn19:32.6.pli: Disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitaṃ?
dn19:32.6.eng: King Disampati is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. Who knows how long he has to live?

dn19:32.7.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati, yaṃ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro bhavantaṃ reṇuṃ rajje abhisiñceyyuṃ.
dn19:32.7.eng: It’s likely that when he passes away the king-makers will anoint you as king.

dn19:32.8.pli: Sace bhavaṃ reṇu rajjaṃ labhetha, saṃvibhajetha no rajjenā’”ti.
dn19:32.8.eng: If you should gain kingship, share it with us.’”

dn19:33.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho, bho, te cha khattiyā mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṃ rājaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn19:33.1.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the six aristocrats. They went to Prince Reṇu and put the proposal to him.

dn19:33.2.pli: “mayaṃ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā;

dn19:33.3.pli: yaṃsukho bhavaṃ taṃsukhā mayaṃ, yaṃdukkho bhavaṃ taṃdukkhā mayaṃ.

dn19:33.4.pli: Disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana bho jānāti jīvitaṃ?

dn19:33.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati, yaṃ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro bhavantaṃ reṇuṃ rajje abhisiñceyyuṃ.

dn19:33.6.pli: Sace bhavaṃ reṇu rajjaṃ labhetha, saṃvibhajetha no rajjenā”ti.

dn19:33.7.pli: “Ko nu kho, bho, añño mama vijite sukho bhavetha, aññatra bhavantebhi?
dn19:33.7.eng: The prince replied, “Who else, sirs, in my realm ought to prosper if not you?
dn19:33.7.comm: Following PTS reading sukhaṁ edheyyātha.

dn19:33.8.pli: Sacāhaṃ, bho, rajjaṃ labhissāmi, saṃvibhajissāmi vo rajjenā”ti.
dn19:33.8.eng: If I gain kingship, I will share it with you all.”

dn19:34.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, ahorattānaṃ accayena rājā disampati kālamakāsi.
dn19:34.1.eng: In due course King Disampati passed away.

dn19:34.2.pli: Disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro reṇuṃ rājaputtaṃ rajje abhisiñciṃsu.
dn19:34.2.eng: At his passing, the king-makers anointed Prince Reṇu as king.

dn19:34.3.pli: Abhisitto reṇu rajjena pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
dn19:34.3.eng: But after being anointed, King Reṇu amused himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

dn19:34.4.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
dn19:34.4.eng: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats and said,

dn19:34.6.pli: Abhisitto reṇu rajjena pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
dn19:34.6.eng: But after being anointed, King Reṇu amused himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

dn19:34.7.pli: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti, madanīyā kāmā?
dn19:34.7.eng: Who knows the intoxicating power of sensual pleasures?

dn19:34.8.pli: Āyantu, bhonto, yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṃ rājānaṃ evaṃ vadetha:
dn19:34.8.eng: Come, sirs, go to Prince Reṇu and say,

dn19:34.9.pli: ‘disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato, abhisitto bhavaṃ reṇu rajjena, sarati bhavaṃ taṃ vacanan’”ti?
dn19:34.9.eng: ‘Worthy sir, King Disampati has passed away, and you have been anointed as king. Do you remember what you said?’”

dn19:34.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho, bho, te cha khattiyā mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṃ rājānaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn19:34.10.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the six aristocrats. They went to King Reṇu and said,

dn19:34.11.pli: “disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato, abhisitto bhavaṃ reṇu rajjena, sarati bhavaṃ taṃ vacanan”ti?
dn19:34.11.eng: “Worthy sir, King Disampati has passed away, and you have been anointed as king. Do you remember what you said?”

dn19:34.13.pli: Ko nu kho, bho, pahoti imaṃ mahāpathaviṃ uttarena āyataṃ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṃ sattadhā samaṃ suvibhattaṃ vibhajitun”ti?
dn19:34.13.eng: Who is able to neatly divide into seven equal parts this great land, so broad in the north and narrow as the front of a cart in the south?”
dn19:34.13.comm: The meaning of sakaṭamukhaṁ (“front of a cart”) is clarified by comparison with the parallels. T 8 is identical (其界廣闊。正南南隅，其界狹略，猶如車形), while DA 3 expresses a similar idea more briefly (此閻浮提地， 內廣外狹). The Mahāvastu (Mvu 85.17) confirms this sense with dakṣiṇena saṁkṣiptā śakaṭamukhasaṁsthitaṁ. These appear to demonstrate a knowledge of the shape of the Indian subcontinent. Below it says that each of the kingdoms is shaped like the front of a cart, just as India is as a whole.

dn19:34.14.pli: “Ko nu kho, bho, añño pahoti, aññatra mahāgovindena brāhmaṇenā”ti?
dn19:34.14.eng: “Who else, sir, if not the Great Steward?”

dn19:35.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, reṇu rājā aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
dn19:35.1.eng: So King Reṇu addressed one of his men,

dn19:35.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ evaṃ vadehi:
dn19:35.2.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to the brahmin Great Steward and say that

dn19:35.4.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho, bho, so puriso reṇussa rañño paṭissutvā yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
dn19:35.4.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.

dn19:35.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tassa purisassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇunā raññā saddhiṃ sammodi.
dn19:35.6.eng: Then the Great Steward went to the king and exchanged greetings with him.

dn19:35.7.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho, bho, mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ reṇu rājā etadavoca:
dn19:35.7.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the king said to him,

dn19:35.8.pli: “etu, bhavaṃ govindo imaṃ mahāpathaviṃ uttarena āyataṃ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṃ sattadhā samaṃ suvibhattaṃ vibhajatū”ti.
dn19:35.8.eng: “Come, let the good Steward neatly divide into seven equal parts this great land, so broad in the north and narrow as the front of a cart in the south.”

dn19:35.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho bho mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo reṇussa rañño paṭissutvā imaṃ mahāpathaviṃ uttarena āyataṃ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṃ sattadhā samaṃ suvibhattaṃ vibhaji.
dn19:35.9.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the Great Steward, and did as he was asked.

dn19:36.1.eng: All were arranged like the fronts of carts,
dn19:36.1.comm: Neither Rhys Davids nor Walshe translate this line, but it receives an extensive discussion in the commentary. It says that six kingdoms were arranged around Reṇu’s kingdom in the middle, like an umbrella (vitānasadisaṁ).

dn19:36.2.pli: Tatra sudaṃ majjhe reṇussa rañño janapado hoti.
dn19:36.2.eng: and right in the middle was King Reṇu’s nation.
dn19:36.2.comm: The verses tell the realms starting with the rising sun at Kaliṅga in the east and proceeding clockwise (padakkhiṇā) until the circle is complete with Aṅga on the Kaliṅga border. Thus the original center was probably the last place on the list, Kāsi, which is indeed geographically central.

dn19:36.3.comm: Kaliṅga was a coastal realm in modern Odisha and Andhra Pradesh. There is no consensus on the exact location of Dantapura.

dn19:36.4.comm: Assaka stretched from Kaliṅga’s western border across the interior. Potana is modern Bodhan in Telangana state.

dn19:36.5.comm: Mahesaya of the Pali editions is a variant spelling for māhissatī; Mahāvastu has māhiṣmatī. It is in present-day Madhya Pradesh, on the banks of Narmada River, and is perhaps to be identified with modern Maheshwar.

dn19:36.6.comm: Sovīra was on the lower Indus, and Roruka is identified with modern Rohri in Sindh province, Pakistan. It is implausible that they received Aryan culture from Kāsi.

dn19:36.7.comm: Mithilā was the capital of Videha, to the north east of the Vajjian federation, nestled against the Himalayas. Mithilā was a dominant kingdom before the Buddha, its king Janaka featuring prominently in early Upaniṣads. It features rarely in the suttas (MN 91, Thig 6.2, Thig 13.4) and had apparently declined in importance. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.10–19 depicts its origins in terms of the spread of fire-worship from the west by its founding king Māthava Videgha with his priest Gotama Rāhūgaṇa.

dn19:36.8.eng: Campā was laid out for the Aṅgas;
dn19:36.8.comm: Campā is modern Champapuri near Bhagalpur in Bihar state, not far from West Bengal. Aṅga lay between the Chandan river to the west and the Rajmahal hills to the east. In the centuries before the Buddha it expanded its dominion to the sea on the south-east and Magadha in the west. But with the Kaliṅgas pushing back from the coast and the rise of Bimbisāra in Magadha, they were pushed back to their ancestral lands and fell under Magadhan dominion.

dn19:36.9.comm: Varanasi, one of the oldest cities in the world, was the capital of the Kāsī kingdom. It lost its status as an independent kingdom shortly before the Buddha, when it was taken over by Kosala. It appears in countless Buddhist stories of the past as the dominant city of the region in what appears to be a timeless and ageless past. However, despite its great antiquity, it is a historical settlement, of which the discovered remains date back to perhaps 1200 BCE; it was a capital city from perhaps 800 BCE.

dn19:36.10.eng: these were laid out by the Steward.

dn19:36.11.pli: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā yathāsakena lābhena attamanā ahesuṃ paripuṇṇasaṅkappā:
dn19:36.11.eng: Then those six aristocrats were delighted with their respective gains, having achieved all they wished for,

dn19:36.12.pli: “yaṃ vata no ahosi icchitaṃ, yaṃ ākaṅkhitaṃ, yaṃ adhippetaṃ, yaṃ abhipatthitaṃ, taṃ no laddhan”ti.
dn19:36.12.eng: “We have received exactly what we wanted, what we wished for, what we desired, what we yearned for.”

dn19:36.13.comm: The names of the aristocrat kings—most of which are difficult to identify from other sources—are listed in an abruptly-inserted verse. The names are missing from the parallels in Mahāvastu and DA 3, but T 8 appears to have the same list of names in the same order, except with Reṇu at the start. Rhys Davids proposes to assign each one to a kingdom as listed in the same order. This seems to work for the first four names, as Ja 424, invoking this sutta, identifies Bharata as king of Sovīra. But it falls apart with Reṇu, who as we have seen, belongs in Kāsi rather than Videha.

dn19:36.14.comm: “Bharata” is the name of an individual king, while they are collectively known as “Bhāratas” (with a long initial ā due to secondary derivation). Ja 424, invoking this sutta, identifies Bharata as king of Sovīra.

dn19:36.16.comm: Here bhāratā means “kings of India” or perhaps, if read together with the preceding verses, “kingdoms of India”. India was called Bhārata after the legendary King Bharata of Hastināpura (Delhi), founder of the Lunar dynasty, conqueror of India, and sire of the warring tribes of the Mahābharata. His story is told in the Saṁbhavapara of the Mahābhārata. The name represents the success of Vedic culture across the subcontinent.

dn19:36.17.eng: The first recitation section is finished.

dn19:37.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn19:37.1.eng: Then the six aristocrats approached the Great Steward and said,

dn19:37.2.pli: “yathā kho bhavaṃ govindo reṇussa rañño sahāyo piyo manāpo appaṭikūlo.
dn19:37.2.eng: “Steward, just as you are King Reṇu’s friend, dear, beloved, and cherished,

dn19:37.3.pli: Evameva kho bhavaṃ govindo amhākampi sahāyo piyo manāpo appaṭikūlo, anusāsatu no bhavaṃ govindo;

dn19:37.4.pli: mā no bhavaṃ govindo anusāsaniyā paccabyāhāsī”ti.
dn19:37.4.eng: Would you manage our affairs? Please don’t turn us down!”

dn19:37.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tesaṃ channaṃ khattiyānaṃ paccassosi.
dn19:37.5.eng: “Yes, worthy sirs,” replied the Great Steward.

dn19:37.6.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo satta ca rājāno khattiye muddhāvasitte rajje anusāsi, satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsāle satta ca nhātakasatāni mante vācesi.
dn19:37.6.eng: Then the Great Steward managed the realms of the seven kings. And he taught seven well-to-do brahmins, and seven hundred bathed initiates to recite the hymns.

dn19:38.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa aparena samayena evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchi:
dn19:38.1.eng: After some time he got this good reputation,

dn19:38.2.pli: “sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṃ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī”ti.
dn19:38.2.eng: “The Great Steward sees the Divinity in person! The Great Steward discusses, converses, and consults with the Divinity in person!”
dn19:38.2.comm: In spiritual circles, such rumors spread like wildfire in an Australian summer.

dn19:38.3.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:

dn19:38.5.pli: ‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṃ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.
dn19:38.5.eng: of seeing the Divinity in person, and discussing with him in person.

dn19:38.6.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ brahmānaṃ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.

dn19:38.7.pli: Sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vuddhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
dn19:38.7.eng: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said:

dn19:38.8.pli: ‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṃ jhānaṃ jhāyati, so brahmānaṃ passati brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.
dn19:38.8.eng: ‘Whoever goes on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practices the absorption on compassion sees the Divinity and discusses with him.’
dn19:38.8.comm: The ancient Brahmanical teachers are invoked to justify the Buddhist rains retreat. | Compassion is one of the “meditations of Brahmā” (brahmavihāra). Normally the suttas speak of the absorptions (jhāna) and of the meditation on compassion (karuṇā), but the idea of an “absorption on compassion” is unique to this sutta.

dn19:38.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyeyyaṃ, karuṇaṃ jhānaṃ jhāyeyyan”ti.

dn19:39.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
dn19:39.1.eng: So the Great Steward went to King Reṇu and told him of the situation, saying,

dn19:39.2.pli: “mayhaṃ kho, bho, evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn19:39.3.pli: ‘sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṃ passati, sakkhi mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmunā sākaccheti sallapati mantetī’ti.

dn19:39.4.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ, bho, brahmānaṃ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi, na brahmunā sallapāmi, na brahmunā mantemi.

dn19:39.5.pli: Sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ vuddhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:

dn19:39.6.pli: ‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṃ jhānaṃ jhāyati, so brahmānaṃ passati, brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.

dn19:39.7.pli: Icchāmahaṃ, bho, vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyituṃ, karuṇaṃ jhānaṃ jhāyituṃ;
dn19:39.7.eng: “Sir, I wish to go on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practice the absorption on compassion.

dn19:39.8.pli: namhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo aññatra ekena bhattābhihārenā”ti.
dn19:39.8.eng: No one should approach me, except for the one who serves my meal.”

dn19:39.9.eng: “Please do so, Steward, at your convenience.”

dn19:43.6.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ brahmānaṃ passāmi, na brahmunā sākacchemi na brahmunā sallapāmi na brahmunā mantemī”ti.
dn19:43.6.eng: But I neither see the Divinity nor discuss with him.”

dn19:44.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, brahmā sanaṅkumāro mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
dn19:44.1.eng: And then the divinity Sanaṅkumāra, knowing the Great Steward’s train of thought, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in the Great Steward’s presence.

dn19:44.2.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa ahudeva bhayaṃ ahu chambhitattaṃ ahu lomahaṃso yathā taṃ adiṭṭhapubbaṃ rūpaṃ disvā.
dn19:44.2.eng: At that, the Great Steward became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end, as he had never seen such a sight before.

dn19:44.3.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo bhīto saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto brahmānaṃ sanaṅkumāraṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
dn19:44.3.eng: So he addressed the divinity Sanaṅkumāra in verse:

dn19:44.7.eng: how am I to know who you are?”

dn19:44.8.eng: “In the realm of divinity they know me

dn19:44.10.eng: All the gods know me thus,

dn19:44.11.eng: and so you should know me, Steward.”

dn19:44.12.eng: “A Divinity deserves a seat and water,

dn19:44.14.eng: Sir, I ask you to please accept

dn19:44.20.eng: about welfare and benefit in this life,

dn19:44.21.eng: or happiness in lives to come.”

dn19:45.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:

dn19:45.2.eng: “the divinity Sanaṅkumāra has granted me an opportunity.

dn19:45.3.pli: Kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ brahmānaṃ sanaṅkumāraṃ puccheyyaṃ diṭṭhadhammikaṃ vā atthaṃ samparāyikaṃ vā”ti?
dn19:45.3.eng: Should I ask him about what is beneficial for this life or lives to come?”

dn19:45.4.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:

dn19:45.5.pli: “kusalo kho ahaṃ diṭṭhadhammikānaṃ atthānaṃ, aññepi maṃ diṭṭhadhammikaṃ atthaṃ pucchanti.
dn19:45.5.eng: “I’m skilled in what is beneficial for this life, and others even ask me about it.

dn19:45.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ brahmānaṃ sanaṅkumāraṃ samparāyikaññeva atthaṃ puccheyyan”ti.
dn19:45.6.eng: Why don’t I ask the Divinity about the benefit that specifically applies to lives to come?”

dn19:45.7.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṃ sanaṅkumāraṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
dn19:45.7.eng: So he addressed the divinity Sanaṅkumāra in verse:

dn19:45.8.eng: “I’m in doubt, so I ask the Divinity—<j>who is free of doubt—

dn19:45.9.eng: about things one may learn from another.

dn19:45.10.eng: Standing on what, training in what

dn19:45.11.eng: may a mortal reach the deathless realm of divinity?”
dn19:45.11.comm: “Deathless” from a Brahmanical perspective, but very much within the realm of saṁsāra from a Buddhist perspective.

dn19:45.12.eng: “He among mankind, O brahmin, has given up possessiveness,
dn19:45.12.comm: Brahme is the normal vocative for brahmā. However in verse it is sometimes used as vocative for brāhmaṇa (eg. Snp 5.1:7.3, Snp 5.19:3.4).

dn19:45.14.eng: free of putrefaction, and refraining from sex.

dn19:46.1.eng: “Sir, I understand what ‘giving up possessiveness’ means.
dn19:46.1.comm: These factors are explained as a summary of the Gradual Training.

dn19:46.2.pli: Idhekacco appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati,
dn19:46.2.eng: It’s when someone gives up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:46.3.eng: That’s how I understand ‘giving up possessiveness’.

dn19:46.4.eng: Sir, I understand what ‘at one’ means.
dn19:46.4.comm: “At one” (ekodibhūta or more commonly ekodibhāva) normally describes deep meditation, and is part of the formula for the second jhāna. Here it is explained as equivalent to “seclusion” (viveka).

dn19:46.5.pli: Idhekacco vivittaṃ senāsanaṃ bhajati araññaṃ rukkhamūlaṃ pabbataṃ kandaraṃ giriguhaṃ susānaṃ vanapatthaṃ abbhokāsaṃ palālapuñjaṃ,
dn19:46.5.eng: It’s when someone frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.

dn19:46.8.pli: Idhekacco karuṇāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadhotiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ karuṇāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
dn19:46.8.eng: It’s when someone meditates spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn19:46.10.pli: Āmagandhe ca kho ahaṃ, bhoto, bhāsamānassa na ājānāmi.
dn19:46.10.eng: But I don’t understand what you say about putrefaction.
dn19:46.10.comm: “Putrefaction” (āmagandha) is the smell of (moral) decay or corruption (AN 3.128, Snp 2.2).

dn19:46.11.eng: What among mankind, O the Divinity, is putrefaction?

dn19:46.12.eng: I don’t understand, so tell me, attentive one:

dn19:46.13.eng: wrapped in what do people stink,

dn19:46.14.eng: headed for hell, shut out of the realm of divinity?”

dn19:46.17.comm: “Desire” is icchā. PTS reads vicikicchā (“doubt”), but this must be incorrect as the commentary explains it as “craving” (taṇhā).

dn19:46.18.pli: Lobho ca doso ca mado ca moho;

dn19:46.19.eng: those bound to such things <j>are not devoid of putrefaction;

dn19:46.20.eng: they’re headed for hell, <j>shut out of the realm of divinity.”

dn19:46.21.pli: “Yathā kho ahaṃ, bhoto, āmagandhe bhāsamānassa ājānāmi. Te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā.
dn19:46.21.eng: “As I understand what you say about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.
dn19:46.21.comm: “Easy to quell” (sunimmadaya) is unique to this passage.

dn19:46.22.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness!”

dn19:46.23.eng: “Please do so, Steward, at your convenience.”

dn19:47.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṃ rājānaṃ etadavoca:
dn19:47.1.eng: So the Great Steward went to King Reṇu and said,

dn19:47.2.pli: “aññaṃ dāni bhavaṃ purohitaṃ pariyesatu, yo bhoto rajjaṃ anusāsissati.
dn19:47.2.eng: “Worthy sir, please now find another high priest to manage the affairs of state for you.

dn19:47.3.eng: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:47.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā.
dn19:47.4.eng: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

dn19:47.5.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:47.8.eng: you must learn how to rule,

dn19:47.9.eng: for I no longer care for my ministry.”

dn19:47.12.eng: I’ll protect you from any harm,

dn19:47.13.eng: for I command the nation’s army.

dn19:47.14.eng: You are my father, I am your son!
dn19:47.14.comm: As noted in the comment to DN 16:5.19.2, kingly clans adopted the lineage name of the high priest (purohita) during initiation.

dn19:47.19.eng: so I no longer care for lay life.”

dn19:47.21.eng: What did he say to you,

dn19:47.23.eng: our house and all our people?”

dn19:47.28.eng: But then the Divinity the Eternal Youth

dn19:47.29.eng: appeared to me from the realm of divinity.

dn19:47.31.eng: hearing which I no longer care for lay life.”

dn19:47.33.eng: in that of which you speak.

dn19:47.40.eng: that’s how pure we shall live,

dn19:47.42.eng: If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”

dn19:47.43.pli: Atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.

dn19:48.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
dn19:48.1.eng: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats and said,

dn19:48.2.pli: “aññaṃ dāni bhavanto purohitaṃ pariyesantu, yo bhavantānaṃ rajje anusāsissati.
dn19:48.2.eng: “Good fellows, please now find another high priest to manage the affairs of state for you.

dn19:48.3.eng: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:48.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā.
dn19:48.4.eng: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

dn19:48.5.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness!”

dn19:49.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
dn19:49.1.eng: Then the six aristocrats withdrew to one side and thought up a plan,

dn19:49.3.pli: yannūna mayaṃ mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ dhanena sikkheyyāmā”ti.
dn19:49.3.eng: Why don’t we bestow him with wealth?”
dn19:49.3.comm: This is a rare use of the verb sikkhati in the sense “bestow, present”.

dn19:49.4.eng: They returned to the Great Steward and said,

dn19:49.5.pli: “saṃvijjati kho, bho, imesu sattasu rajjesu pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ, tato bhoto yāvatakena attho, tāvatakaṃ āharīyatan”ti.
dn19:49.5.eng: “In these seven kingdoms there is abundant wealth. We’ll get you as much as you want.”

dn19:49.6.pli: “Alaṃ, bho, mamapidaṃ pahūtaṃ sāpateyyaṃ bhavantānaṃyeva vāhasā.
dn19:49.6.eng: “Enough, sirs. I already have abundant wealth, owing to my lords.

dn19:49.7.pli: Tamahaṃ sabbaṃ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāmi.
dn19:49.7.eng: Giving up all that, I shall go forth.”

dn19:49.8.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,

dn19:49.10.pli: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā ekamantaṃ apakkamma evaṃ samacintesuṃ:
dn19:49.10.eng: Then the six aristocrats withdrew to one side and thought up a plan,

dn19:49.12.pli: yannūna mayaṃ mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ itthīhi sikkheyyāmā”ti.
dn19:49.12.eng: Why don’t we bestow him with women?”

dn19:49.13.eng: They returned to the Great Steward and said,

dn19:49.14.pli: “saṃvijjanti kho, bho, imesu sattasu rajjesu pahūtā itthiyo, tato bhoto yāvatikāhi attho, tāvatikā ānīyatan”ti.
dn19:49.14.eng: “In these seven kingdoms there are many women. We’ll get you as many as you want.”

dn19:49.15.eng: “Enough, sirs. I already have forty equal wives.

dn19:49.16.pli: Tāpāhaṃ sabbā pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāmi.
dn19:49.16.eng: Giving up all them, I shall go forth.”

dn19:49.17.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,

dn19:50.1.pli: “Sace bhavaṃ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
dn19:50.1.eng: “If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”

dn19:50.2.eng: “If you all give up sensual pleasures,

dn19:50.3.eng: to which ordinary people are attached,

dn19:50.5.eng: and possessing the power of patience.

dn19:50.6.eng: This path is the straight path,

dn19:50.8.eng: Guarded by the good, the true teaching
dn19:50.8.comm: “True teaching” (saddhamma) normally describes the Buddha’s teaching.

dn19:50.9.eng: leads to rebirth in the realm of divinity.”
dn19:50.9.comm: “Leads to rebirth in the Brahmā realm” (brahmalokūpapattiyā), just as the teaching of Āḷāra Kālāma, based on the even more refined formless meditations, leads to rebirth in the dimension of nothingness (MN 36:14.14).

dn19:51.1.pli: “Tena hi bhavaṃ govindo satta vassāni āgametu.
dn19:51.1.eng: “Well then, sir, please wait for seven years.

dn19:51.2.pli: Sattannaṃ vassānaṃ accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
dn19:51.2.eng: When seven years have passed, we shall go forth with you. Your destiny shall be ours.”

dn19:51.3.pli: “Aticiraṃ kho, bho, satta vassāni, nāhaṃ sakkomi, bhavante, satta vassāni āgametuṃ.
dn19:51.3.eng: “Seven years is too long, sirs. I cannot wait that long.

dn19:51.4.pli: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitānaṃ.
dn19:51.4.eng: Who knows what will happen to the living?

dn19:51.5.pli: Gamanīyo samparāyo, mantāyaṃ boddhabbaṃ, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṃ.
dn19:51.5.eng: We are heading to the next life. We must be thoughtful and wake up! We must do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.
dn19:51.5.comm: Echoing the ancient hermit Araka at AN 7.74:2.2, who said life is evanescent like a dewdrop.

dn19:51.6.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,

dn19:52.1.eng: “Well then, sir, please wait for six years,

dn19:52.6.pli: ekaṃ vassaṃ āgametu, ekassa vassassa accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.

dn19:53.1.pli: “Aticiraṃ kho, bho, ekaṃ vassaṃ, nāhaṃ sakkomi bhavante ekaṃ vassaṃ āgametuṃ.

dn19:53.2.pli: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitānaṃ.

dn19:53.3.pli: Gamanīyo samparāyo, mantāyaṃ boddhabbaṃ, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṃ.

dn19:53.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,

dn19:53.6.pli: “Tena hi bhavaṃ govindo satta māsāni āgametu, sattannaṃ māsānaṃ accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.

dn19:54.1.pli: “Aticiraṃ kho, bho, satta māsāni, nāhaṃ sakkomi bhavante satta māsāni āgametuṃ.

dn19:54.2.pli: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitānaṃ.

dn19:54.3.pli: Gamanīyo samparāyo, mantāyaṃ boddhabbaṃ, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṃ.

dn19:54.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,

dn19:54.6.pli: “Tena hi bhavaṃ govindo cha māsāni āgametu …pe…

dn19:54.12.pli: addhamāsaṃ āgametu, addhamāsassa accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
dn19:54.12.eng: or even a fortnight. When a fortnight has passed, we shall go forth. Your destiny shall be ours.”

dn19:55.1.pli: “Aticiraṃ kho, bho, addhamāso, nāhaṃ sakkomi bhavante addhamāsaṃ āgametuṃ.
dn19:55.1.eng: “A fortnight is too long, sirs. I cannot wait that long.

dn19:55.2.pli: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitānaṃ.
dn19:55.2.eng: Who knows what will happen to the living?

dn19:55.3.pli: Gamanīyo samparāyo, mantāyaṃ boddhabbaṃ, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṃ.
dn19:55.3.eng: We are heading to the next life. We must be thoughtful and wake up! We must do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.

dn19:55.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,
dn19:55.4.eng: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

dn19:55.5.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

dn19:55.6.pli: “Tena hi bhavaṃ govindo sattāhaṃ āgametu, yāva mayaṃ sake puttabhātaro rajjena anusāsissāma, sattāhassa accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
dn19:55.6.eng: “Well then, sir, please wait for a week, so that we can instruct our sons and brothers in kingship. When a week has passed, we shall go forth. Your destiny shall be ours.”

dn19:55.7.pli: “Na ciraṃ kho, bho, sattāhaṃ, āgamessāmahaṃ bhavante sattāhan”ti.
dn19:55.7.eng: “A week is not too long, sirs. I will wait that long.”

dn19:56.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā satta ca nhātakasatāni tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsāle satta ca nhātakasatāni etadavoca:
dn19:56.1.eng: Then the Great Steward also went to the seven well-to-do brahmins and seven hundred bathed initiates and said,

dn19:56.2.pli: “aññaṃ dāni bhavanto ācariyaṃ pariyesantu, yo bhavantānaṃ mante vācessati.
dn19:56.2.eng: “Good fellows, please now find another tutor to teach you to recite the hymns.

dn19:56.3.eng: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:56.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa. Te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā,
dn19:56.4.eng: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

dn19:56.5.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

dn19:56.6.eng: “Please don’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness!

dn19:56.7.pli: Pabbajjā, bho, appesakkhā ca appalābhā ca;
dn19:56.7.eng: The life of one gone forth is of little influence or profit,

dn19:56.8.eng: whereas the life of a brahmin is of great influence and profit.”

dn19:56.9.pli: “Mā bhavanto evaṃ avacuttha: ‘pabbajjā appesakkhā ca appalābhā ca, brahmaññaṃ mahesakkhañca mahālābhañcā’ti.

dn19:56.10.pli: Ko nu kho, bho, aññatra mayā mahesakkhataro vā mahālābhataro vā.
dn19:56.10.eng: Who has greater influence and profit than myself?

dn19:56.11.pli: Ahañhi, bho, etarahi rājāva raññaṃ brahmāva brāhmaṇānaṃ devatāva gahapatikānaṃ.
dn19:56.11.eng: For now I am like a king to kings, like the Divinity to brahmins, like a deity to householders.

dn19:56.12.pli: Tamahaṃ sabbaṃ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāmi.
dn19:56.12.eng: Giving up all that, I shall go forth.

dn19:56.13.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā.
dn19:56.13.eng: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

dn19:56.14.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

dn19:56.15.pli: “Sace bhavaṃ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
dn19:56.15.eng: “If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”

dn19:57.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena cattārīsā bhariyā sādisiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā cattārīsā bhariyā sādisiyo etadavoca:
dn19:57.1.eng: Then the Great Steward went to his forty equal wives and said,

dn19:57.2.pli: “yā bhotīnaṃ icchati, sakāni vā ñātikulāni gacchatu aññaṃ vā bhattāraṃ pariyesatu.
dn19:57.2.eng: “Ladies, please do whatever you wish, whether returning to your own families, or finding another husband.

dn19:57.3.eng: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:57.4.pli: Yathā kho pana me sutaṃ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā.
dn19:57.4.eng: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.

dn19:57.5.eng: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

dn19:57.6.pli: “Tvaññeva no ñāti ñātikāmānaṃ, tvaṃ pana bhattā bhattukāmānaṃ.
dn19:57.6.eng: “You are the only family we want! You are the only husband we want!

dn19:57.7.pli: Sace bhavaṃ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
dn19:57.7.eng: If you are going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”
dn19:57.7.comm: It is regarded as normal that woman should renounce.

dn19:58.1.pli: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tassa sattāhassa accayena kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbaji.
dn19:58.1.eng: When a week had passed, the Great Steward shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn19:58.2.pli: Pabbajitaṃ pana mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ satta ca rājāno khattiyā muddhāvasittā satta ca brāhmaṇamahāsālā satta ca nhātakasatāni cattārīsā ca bhariyā sādisiyo anekāni ca khattiyasahassāni anekāni ca brāhmaṇasahassāni anekāni ca gahapatisahassāni anekehi ca itthāgārehi itthiyo kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā mahāgovindaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitaṃ anupabbajiṃsu.
dn19:58.2.eng: And when he had gone forth, the seven anointed aristocrat kings, the seven brahmins with seven hundred initiates, the forty equal wives, and many thousands of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and many harem women shaved off their hair and beards, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn19:58.2.comm: Compare with the mass renunciation under Vipassī (DN 14:2.16.6).

dn19:58.3.pli: Tāya sudaṃ, bho, parisāya parivuto mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo gāmanigamarājadhānīsu cārikaṃ carati.
dn19:58.3.eng: Escorted by that assembly, the Great Steward wandered on tour among the villages, towns, and capital cities.

dn19:58.4.pli: Yaṃ kho pana, bho, tena samayena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo gāmaṃ vā nigamaṃ vā upasaṅkamati, tattha rājāva hoti raññaṃ, brahmāva brāhmaṇānaṃ, devatāva gahapatikānaṃ.
dn19:58.4.eng: And at that time, whenever he arrived at a village or town, he was like a king to kings, like the Divinity to brahmins, like a deity to householders.

dn19:58.5.pli: Tena kho pana samayena manussā khipanti vā upakkhalanti vā.
dn19:58.5.eng: And whenever people sneezed or tripped over

dn19:58.7.eng: “Homage to the Great Steward! Homage to the high priest for the seven!”

dn19:59.1.pli: Mahāgovindo, bho, brāhmaṇo mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā vihāsi, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā vihāsi.
dn19:59.1.eng: And the Great Steward meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
dn19:59.1.comm: His meditation expands from compassion to include all four of the brahmavihāras.

dn19:59.2.eng: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …

dn19:59.4.eng: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

dn19:59.5.eng: And he taught his disciples the path to rebirth in the company of Divinity.

dn19:60.1.pli: Ye kho pana, bho, tena samayena mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa sāvakā sabbenasabbaṃ sāsanaṃ ājāniṃsu.
dn19:60.1.eng: Those of his disciples who completely understood the Great Steward’s instructions,

dn19:60.2.pli: Te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ brahmalokaṃ upapajjiṃsu.
dn19:60.2.eng: at the breaking up of the body, after death, were reborn in the realm of divinity.

dn19:60.3.pli: Ye na sabbenasabbaṃ sāsanaṃ ājāniṃsu, te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā appekacce paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjiṃsu;
dn19:60.3.eng: Of those disciples who only partly understood the Great Steward’s instructions, some were reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others,

dn19:60.4.eng: while some were reborn in the company of the gods who love to create,

dn19:60.7.eng: or the gods of the thirty-three,

dn19:60.8.eng: or the gods of the four great kings.

dn19:60.9.pli: ye sabbanihīnaṃ kāyaṃ paripūresuṃ te gandhabbakāyaṃ paripūresuṃ.
dn19:60.9.eng: And at the very least they swelled the hosts of the centaurs.

dn19:60.10.pli: Iti kho, bho, sabbesaṃyeva tesaṃ kulaputtānaṃ amoghā pabbajjā ahosi avañjhā saphalā saudrayā’ti.
dn19:60.10.eng: And so the going forth of all those gentlemen was not in vain, was not wasted, but was fruitful and fertile.’

dn19:60.11.eng: Do you remember this, Blessed One?”

dn19:61.2.pli: Ahaṃ tena samayena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo ahosiṃ.
dn19:61.2.eng: I myself was the brahmin Great Steward at that time.
dn19:61.2.comm: This is the third and final Jātaka in the Dīghanikāya, after DN 5 and DN 17.

dn19:61.3.pli: Ahaṃ tesaṃ sāvakānaṃ brahmalokasahabyatāya maggaṃ desesiṃ.
dn19:61.3.eng: And I taught those disciples the path to rebirth in the company of Divinity.

dn19:61.4.pli: Taṃ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ na nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati, yāvadeva brahmalokūpapattiyā.
dn19:61.4.eng: But that spiritual path of mine doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the realm of divinity.
dn19:61.4.comm: According to the doctrine of the “perfections” (pāramī), which emerged around two to four centuries after the Buddha’s passing, the practices he undertook in past lives laid the foundation for awakening in this life. Here, however, the Buddha states that his former practices did not lead to awakening. Rather, since they were based on the wrong view of eternal bliss in the Brahmā realm, they only led to a good rebirth so long as that kamma lasted. It is the eightfold path, which the Buddha discovered in his final life, which leads to awakening. The same saying in a similar context is found at MN 83:21.7.

dn19:61.5.pli: Idaṃ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
dn19:61.5.eng: But this spiritual path does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

dn19:61.6.pli: Katamañca taṃ, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati?
dn19:61.6.eng: And what is the spiritual path that leads to extinguishment?

dn19:61.7.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

dn19:61.8.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
dn19:61.8.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

dn19:61.9.pli: Idaṃ kho taṃ, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṃvattati.
dn19:61.9.eng: This is the spiritual path that leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.

dn19:62.1.pli: Ye kho pana me, pañcasikha, sāvakā sabbenasabbaṃ sāsanaṃ ājānanti, te āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti;
dn19:62.1.eng: Those of my disciples who completely understand my instructions realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

dn19:62.2.pli: ye na sabbenasabbaṃ sāsanaṃ ājānanti, te pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātikā honti tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
dn19:62.2.eng: Of those disciples who only partly understand my instructions, some, with the ending of the five lower fetters, become reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

dn19:62.3.pli: Ye na sabbenasabbaṃ sāsanaṃ ājānanti, appekacce tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmino honti sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karissanti.
dn19:62.3.eng: Some, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

dn19:62.4.pli: Ye na sabbenasabbaṃ sāsanaṃ ājānanti, appekacce tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpannā honti avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
dn19:62.4.eng: And some, with the ending of three fetters, become stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

dn19:62.5.pli: Iti kho, pañcasikha, sabbesaṃyeva imesaṃ kulaputtānaṃ amoghā pabbajjā avañjhā saphalā saudrayā”ti.
dn19:62.5.eng: And so the going forth of all those gentlemen was not in vain, was not wasted, but was fruitful and fertile.”

dn19:62.6.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn19:62.7.pli: Attamano pañcasikho gandhabbaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.
dn19:62.7.eng: Delighted, the centaur Pañcasikha approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
